title-group.article-title: Carotid Doppler Velocity Measurements and Anatomic Stenosis
title-group.subtitle: Correlation Is Futile

article-meta.aff: 1Ultrasound Reading Center and the D.E. Strandness Jr. Vascular Laboratory at the University of Washington Medical Center, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
2Department of Surgery, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
3Applied Physics Laboratory, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA

author-notes.corresp: R. Eugene Zierler, Department of Surgery, University of Washington, 1959 N.E. Pacific St., Seattle, WA 98195, USA Email: gzierler@u.washington.edu

abstract.p: Background: Duplex ultrasound with Doppler velocimetry is widely used to evaluate the presence and severity of internal carotid artery stenosis; however, a variety of velocity criteria are currently being applied to classify stenosis severity. The purpose of this study is to compare published Doppler velocity measurements to the severity of internal carotid artery stenosis as assessed by x-ray angiography in order to clarify the relationship between these 2 widely used approaches to assess carotid artery disease. Methods: Scatter diagrams or “scattergrams” of correlations between Doppler velocity measurements and stenosis severity as assessed by x-ray contrast angiography were obtained from published articles for native and stented internal carotid arteries. The scattergrams were graphically digitized, combined, and segmented into categories bounded by 50% and 70% diameter reduction. These data were combined and divided into 3 sets representing different velocity parameters: (1) peak systolic velocity, (2) end-diastolic velocity, and (3) the internal carotid artery to common carotid artery peak systolic velocity ratio. The horizontal axis of each scattergram was transformed to form a cumulative distribution function, and thresholds were established for the stenosis categories to assess data variability. Results: Nineteen publications with 22 data sets were identified and included in this analysis. Wide variability was apparent between all 3 velocity parameters and angiographic percent stenosis. The optimal peak systolic velocity thresholds for stenosis in stented carotid arteries were higher than those for native carotid arteries. Within each category of stenosis, the variability of all 3 velocity parameters was significantly lower in stented arteries than in native arteries. Conclusion: Although Doppler velocity criteria have been successfully used to classify the severity of stenosis in both native and stented carotid arteries, the relationship to angiographic stenosis contains significant variability. This analysis of published studies suggests that further refinements in Doppler velocity criteria will not lead to improved correlation with carotid stenosis as demonstrated by angiography.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Based on the pioneering development of x-ray contrast agents for cerebral angiography by neurosurgeon Egaz Moniz and the meticulous anatomic investigations of carotid artery stenosis related to stroke by neurologist C. Miller Fisher, percent diameter reduction (DR) stenosis of the internal carotid artery has been the standard method of predicting the risk of atheroembolic stroke for half a century. Using an ultrasonic Doppler and B-mode imaging system combined into a duplex scanner with the addition of a real-time spectrum analyzer, vascular surgeon D. Eugene Strandness Jr lead a team of research fellows and vascular sonographers in the development of a noninvasive method for classifying the severity of carotid artery stenosis. 1 –3 Since the development of that Doppler method more than 3 decades ago, the correlation between anatomic x-ray angiography and physiologic duplex Doppler velocimetry has been a subject of recurrent scrutiny.

In 2002, Grant convened the “consensus conference” on the measurement of carotid stenosis which reproduced a figure showing the relationship between Doppler velocity and decile categories of angiographic stenosis, noting the “marked overlap (of velocity ranges) in adjacent categories.” 4,5 The consensus conference panel noted “tremendous variability” between diagnostic thresholds for predicting angiographic stenosis categories, suggesting that each ultrasound laboratory should develop their own criteria. Subsequent to the consensus report, there have been a series of publications showing scatter diagrams or “scattergrams” of correlations between carotid angiography and Doppler velocity measurements, 6
–25 with some differentiating between patient genders, 6 instrument manufacturers, 7 and artery treatment status. 8 The belief that a normal patent stented artery exhibits higher velocities than a normal native carotid artery is widely accepted. 8,19 –21,24,25

The purpose of this study is to combine published Doppler velocity measurements from a variety of authors and compare them with the severity of internal carotid artery stenosis as assessed by x-ray angiography to clarify the relationship between these 2 widely used approaches to assess carotid artery disease. This technique of compiling results from multiple sources into a single data set should provide a new and unique perspective on this issue.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Using the National Library of Medicine PubMed search engine, publications containing scattergrams comparing carotid artery anatomic measurements with ultrasonic Doppler velocimetry were obtained. Each scattergram was extracted from the publication as an image for processing. Scattergram values were manually digitized from the graphs point by point using a custom software program written in MATLAB (The MathWorks, Natick, Massachusetts). All points were then rendered in Microsoft Excel on uniform axes for display and analysis. Negative percent DR was converted to zero. 20,21 Data from all studies were combined into a single data list, separated into 3 sets by: (1) systolic velocity (measured at the peak of the waveform), (2) diastolic velocity (measured at end-diastole), and (3) the ratio of internal carotid artery peak systolic velocity to common carotid artery peak systolic velocity (ICA/CCA ratio). Velocities were reported in centimeters per second (cm/s) and ratios were rounded to 2 significant digits. Overall trends were observed by least squared deviation quadratic curve fitting provided as an Excel function.

Carotid arteries were separated into 3 DR categories based on angiography: <50% DR, 50% to 70% DR, and >70% DR. For each of the 3 stenosis categories, a cumulative distribution plot was created by sorting the cases into velocity (or ratio) order, then numbering the measurements in order and computing the within-category percentile by dividing by the number of cases in the category. The horizontal axis of each scattergram shows the percentile plotted versus velocity (or ratio) to form a cumulative distribution function. Thresholds were established from each cumulative distribution function, balancing percent false positives with percent false negatives from adjacent classifications. Data variability was measured by computing the categorical cumulative distribution function slope as double the difference between the 75th percentile and the 25th percentile values. Probabilities were computed from proportions using Student t test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 19 publications with 22 data sets by 17 lead authors were identified, including 13 publications containing data on native carotid arteries, 0 on endarterectomized carotid arteries, and 8 on stented carotid arteries. Nineteen publications included ICA systolic velocity data, 13 included ICA diastolic velocity data, and 14 included ICA/CCA ratio data.

The “tremendous variability” mentioned by Grant5 in the relationship between systolic velocity and percent stenosis is present in all of the published data sets with sufficient numbers of cases (Figure 1). The quadratic curves fitting the native and stented carotid artery data are similar until 50% DR is exceeded. Wide variability in the published data is also present in the relationship between diastolic velocity and percent stenosis (Figure 2) and in the ICA/CCA ratio data (Figure 3).

caption.p: Systolic carotid velocity versus percent diameter reduction by angiography. Compiled results from 19 publications with velocity/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 2996 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open symbols; stented arteries are represented by solid symbols. Letters after reference numbers indicate separation of cases into males (M) or females (F) and native (N) or stented (S).

Diastolic carotid velocity versus percent diameter reduction by angiography. Compiled results from 13 publications with velocity/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 1385 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open symbols; stented arteries are represented by solid symbols. Letters after reference numbers indicate separation of cases into males (M) or females (F) and native (N) or stented (S).

The internal carotid artery peak systolic velocity to common carotid artery peak systolic velocity (ICA/CCA) ratio versus percent diameter reduction by angiography. Compiled results from 14 publications with velocity/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 2144 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open symbols; stented arteries are represented by solid symbols. Letters after reference numbers indicate separation of cases into males (M) or females (F) and native (N) or stented (S).

sec.p: A quantitative measure of the diagnostic merit of systolic velocity can be gleaned from cumulative distribution plots segmented by angiographic classification. In Figure 4, the best systolic velocity criterion for differentiating >70% DR from 50% to 70% DR is 320 cm/s in stents and 280 cm/s in native arteries. For the stents, 80% of the >70% DR arteries lie above 320 cm/s and 80% of the 50% to 70% DR arteries lie below the threshold. Similarly, for native arteries, 67.6% of >70% DR lie above 280 cm/s while 67.6% of the 50% to 70% DR arteries lie below the threshold. The best systolic velocity criterion for differentiating 50% to 70% DR from <50% DR is 170 cm/s in stents and 165 cm/s in native arteries.

caption.p: Cumulative distribution of systolic velocity for stenosis classifications. Compiled results from 19 publications with velocity/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 2996 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open figures; stented arteries are represented by solid figures. The upper pair of curves is from arteries with greater than 70% angiographic diameter reduction; the middle pair is from arteries with 50% to 70% diameter reduction; the lower pair is from arteries with less than 50% diameter reduction. Dashed lines and open circles show optimum thresholds for native arteries; solid lines and cyan circles show optimum thresholds for stented arteries.

sec.p: In Figure 5, the best diastolic velocity criterion for differentiating >70% DR from 50% to 70% DR is 104 cm/s in stents and 132 cm/s in native arteries. For the stents, 71.8% of the >70% DR arteries lie above 104 cm/s and 71.8% of the 50% to 70% DR arteries lie below the threshold. Similarly, for native arteries, 65.2% of >70% DR lie above 132 cm/s while 65.2% of the 50% to 70% DR arteries lie below the threshold. The best diastolic velocity criterion for differentiating 50% to 70% DR from <50% DR is 58 cm/s for both stented and native arteries.

caption.p: Cumulative distribution of diastolic velocity for stenosis classifications. Compiled results from 13 publications with velocity/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 1385 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open symbols; stented arteries are represented by solid symbols. The upper pair of curves is from arteries with greater than 70% angiographic diameter reduction; the middle pair is from arteries with 50% to 70% diameter reduction; the lower pair is from arteries with less than 50% diameter reduction. Dashed lines and open circles show optimum thresholds for native arteries; solid lines and cyan circles show optimum thresholds for stented arteries.

sec.p: In Figure 6, the best ICA/CCA ratio criterion for differentiating >70% DR from 50% to 70% DR is 3.88 in stents and 4.35 in native arteries. For the stents, 69.7% of the >70% DR stented arteries lie above 3.88 and 69.7% of the 50% to 70% DR stented arteries lie below the threshold. Similarly, for native arteries, 66.1% of >70% DR lie above 4.35 while 66.1% of the 50% to 70% DR arteries lie below the threshold. The best velocity ratio criterion for differentiating 50% to 70% DR from < 50% DR is 2.39 for stented and native arteries.

caption.p: Cumulative distribution of internal carotid artery peak systolic velocity to common carotid artery peak systolic velocity (ICA/CCA) ratio for stenosis classifications. Compiled results from 14 publications with velocity-ratio/stenosis scattergrams between 1995 and 2010 including 2144 measurements. Native arteries are represented by open symbols; stented arteries are represented by solid symbols. The upper pair of curves is from arteries with greater than 70% angiographic diameter reduction; the middle pair is from arteries with 50% to 70% diameter reduction; the lower pair is from arteries with less than 50% diameter reduction. Dashed lines and open circles show optimum thresholds for native arteries; solid lines and cyan circles show optimum thresholds for stented arteries.

sec.p: The values from Figures 4, 5, and 6 are summarized in Table 1. Stenotic systolic velocities in stented arteries are slightly higher than those in native arteries; stenotic diastolic velocities in stented arteries are slightly lower than those in native arteries, as are the ICA/CCA ratios. The within-category variability of systolic and diastolic velocities, as well as ICA/CCA ratios, is significantly lower in stented arteries than in native arteries (P < .01).

fn.p: Abbreviations: DR, diameter reduction; ICA/CCA ratio, ratio of internal carotid artery peak systolic velocity to common carotid artery peak systolic velocity.
a Bolded values correspond to the thresholds in Figures 4, 5, and 6.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The relationship between carotid angiographic stenosis and Doppler velocity does not form a narrow monotonic line; an intrinsic variability exists in the relationship between carotid anatomic stenosis as revealed by contrast x-ray angiography and velocity derived from ultrasonic Doppler measurements. This variability is so extreme that even experts might be reluctant to publish their results (Johnston KW, personal communication, June 2011). Favorable estimates of test accuracy in the literature may result from a tendency for only centers demonstrating high accuracy to publish their results. 26

The sources of variability shown in Figures 1 through 6 include (1) between-patient factors, such as individual differences in collateral intracranial connections 27 ; (2) variability between facilities in Doppler protocol or equipment 7 ; (3) variability in acquiring Doppler measurements 28 ; (4) variability in measuring Doppler velocities 29 ; (5) variability within patients due to carbon dioxide exposure, caffeine, lactate, nicotine, metabolic tolerance, regional brain activation, or other factors affecting physiology 30
–34 ; (6) variability in angiography technique 35 ; (7) variability in measuring the residual lumen diameter and normal lumen diameter on angiograms 36,37 ; and (8) changes in the severity of stenosis between obtaining the Doppler ultrasound measurements and the angiographic images.

In 2 studies of angiographic variability, 2 readers differed by 20% DR in 8% 35 to 17% 36 of cases when reading the same preselected images. When comparing 2 views (biplane angiography) read by a single angiographer, 60% of the readings differed by more than 20% DR. The higher variability in the biplane readings is a worst-case measure of the repeatability of angiography acquisition, including the variations due to noncircular stenoses and due to acquisitions taken at different times in the cardiac cycle (systole or diastole). In the present study, considering the 20% range between 50% and 70% DR, 56.1% (100% − [67.6% − 23.7%]) of the native arteries lie outside the systolic criterion range of 170 to 280 cm/s and 29.4% (100% − [80% − 9.4%]) of the stented arteries lie outside the systolic criterion range of 170 to 320 cm/s.

Table 2 compares the diagnostic reliability of repeat angiography and ultrasound. Although not tested for statistical significance, comparing 2 angiographic views appears to have the poorest agreement (75% of cases change in classification) followed by ultrasound versus angiography in native arteries. Inter-reader variability in angiography is similar to ultrasound versus angiography in stented arteries, which is comparable to the paired ultrasound studies.

caption.p: Exam Disagreement for Angiographic 50% to 69% Classification

fn.p: Abbreviations: DR, diameter reduction; I, ipsilateral; C, contralateral.

sec.p: Two factors contribute to the between-acquisition angiographic variability: (1) noncircularity of the stenosis and (2) pulsatile changes in the minimum lumen diameter. The exposure time in angiography is much shorter than either systole or diastole, thus the minimum lumen diameter measurement depends on exposure timing in the cardiac cycle. The diameter change in a normal carotid artery during the cardiac cycle is about 0.2 mm in a 4 mm diameter artery, 37 increasing in systole and decreasing in diastole. However, in stenotic arteries, the Bernoulli effect can cause a paradoxical pulsation, causing the diameter to decrease in diameter by as much as 0.2 mm in systole. 38 This can have a significant effect on the remaining diameter of a 1 mm diameter stenosis, reducing the area by 40% during systole. This amount is resolvable by angiographers, but without a cardiac cycle-gated angiographic acquisition to differentiate systole from diastole, the variation would be random. When a stent is present, the area pulsation decreases by a factor of 3, 20 decreasing this source of variability. The lumen of a stented artery is also more likely to be circular than the lumen of a diseased native artery. These factors may contribute to the lower variability observed in the scattergrams for the relationship between Doppler velocity measurements and angiographic stenosis severity in stented carotid arteries.

There is a wide variation in the published velocity criteria for differentiating important degrees of carotid stenosis (Table 3). Such differences would be expected in a small or moderate sample of cases taken from a population with large variability. When the criteria are retrospectively adjusted to maximize the values for sensitivity and specificity, the results can be respectable, but such a method does not provide prospective validation for the criteria.

caption.p: Published Doppler Criteria for Classification of Carotid Stenosis

fn.p: Abbreviations: M, males; F, females; I, ipsilateral; C, contralateral.

sec.p: It has been shown that the presence of a severe symptomatic carotid stenosis carries a 22.2% risk of ipsilateral stroke at 60 months in medically treated patients. 39 This observation has launched a series of studies to identify the “vulnerable plaque” to separate those patients at risk of carotid atheroembolic stroke from those without risk. 40 Most of these efforts focus on the content of the plaque (lipid, hemorrhage, or calcium), 41 –43 plaque motion, 44 or cap thickness. 45,46 Other work has focused on the detection of emboli in the cerebral vessels 47 and cerebral collateralization. 48 So far, none of these studies has resulted in the certain identification of those patients with carotid stenosis who are most likely to benefit from carotid revascularization.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Although the duplex Doppler examination is widely utilized to evaluate carotid stenosis and atheroembolic stroke potential, the relationship to angiographic stenosis contains significant variability. Despite this limitation, Doppler velocity criteria have been successfully used in the clinical setting to classify the severity of carotid disease within broad ranges for more than 3 decades. The existence of multiple sets of criteria, even with standardized examination protocols and instrumentation, is further evidence of the intrinsic variability in this relationship. The analysis reported here suggests that further refinements in Doppler velocity criteria will not lead to improved correlation with carotid stenosis as demonstrated by angiography. Therefore, while the classification of stenosis severity remains clinically relevant, it is likely that the future role of carotid ultrasound in the assessment of stroke risk will focus on other features of atherosclerotic plaque.

fn.label: Author’s Note
fn.p: For full color versions of Figures 1–6 please refer to the journal website at http://ves.sagepub.com/

Also would like to thank Atherosclerotic Plaque Neovascular Inflation providing the data for the work of Canxing Xu at the University of Washington Bioengineering Image Computing Laboratory for their support.
